text: it's my last day at overview farms and i i don't know where the time has gone um and i have to say i didn't expect to like working with cows as much as i did um i've been here a month now and i've kind of made friends with a few of them um they've all got their own personalities so i wanted to introduce a couple of my favorites to you this is granny she's my absolute favorite and poor granny she can't walk very well she's getting old she's got stuff in her feet we've put some blocks on her to try and help her walk but it's it's a chore for her getting around i come around in the morning and i get her out of her stall and she's always the last one and she'll sort of make her way slowly down towards the milking parlor and she'll look behind her as if she's saying are you sure are you sure i have to go down there and say yes and she will she'll eventually make it down and she'll eventually make it back and i just i guess i just admire her persistence but yeah i've got a soft spot for granny and this is annabelle and annabelle has got to be the most stubborn cow on the farm she was made a pet by the daughter of the heifer razor when she was off farm and so she doesn't think she has to listen and so when i come and get her up in the morning she'll be sitting in her stall and i'll come along and okay cows time to get up and she'll be sitting in her stall and she'll look at me she said what are you gonna do about it and so i'll i'll come and i'll have to stand next to her and i'll give her a pat and you know let her know hey it's time to go and eventually she'll get up but in her time but despite all of her stubbornness she's super curious and super comfortable around people and when i'm around she'll come and knows and she'll just want to come and see what i'm doing and she's just really really friendly and kind of frustrating when you want to do something so we've got about 120 cows here and as you can imagine 120 cows they eat a lot of food in fact they eat about two and a half tons of food twice a day and well two and a half tons is a lot of feed so we can't just sort of bring it out in wheelbarrows we need bigger machinery and it's pretty simple this is a feed mixer if you look inside there's two corkscrews going around turning and mixing the feed and then robert toes the feed mixer down the aisles of the barn and the feed mixer just dispenses a line of food right where the cows can get it so this feed mixer is actually really important because the amount of milk that the cows produce is tied to what they eat and so a lot of thought goes into getting the nutrition for the cows just right so i want to share well what do cows eat so this bale here this is not hay um and the plastic that it's wrapping is actually really functional because when it's wrapped up and made airtight what starts out is hay inside ferments and turns into what's called grass silage which i think is a little bit easier for the cows to digest and to that you add a little bit of milled corn which adds calories and energy you'll add a little bit of soy meal or maybe some canola to add protein which helps keep the milk production up you'll add some minerals and some room and bypass fat which i think helps bulk them up and then you'll top it all off with another scoop of fermented hay this is also grass silage but stored in a silo rather than in a veil and you mix all that up and that's what cows eat so this is my last day at overview farms and it's actually the last video i'm going to make while i'm on a farm i've been on the road for eight months now and i've been filming the whole time so i really hope i have enough footage to make a pretty decent documentary but that means i'm going to take a hiatus from these videos for a couple weeks as i drive from nova scotia all the way back to british columbia where i'm going to edit the film and then once i start editing the film i'll start posting videos again with some highlights of the footage or maybe good interview clips so i'll keep posting videos and you can catch those videos by subscribing to the youtube channel you can find out more about the big picture of the documentary by going to the handset fetus.ca you can follow me on facebook and instagram and i'll see you in a couple weeks when i get back to british columbia
